If your opponent continues to use fallacies despite your efforts to call them out, it can be frustrating. Here are a few tips to keep the conversation productive:

1. Take a break - If you feel like the conversation is going nowhere, take a break. Agree to resume the discussion at a later time when both of you are less emotional and more open to listening.

2. Reframe the conversation - If you feel like you're talking past each other, try to reframe the discussion. Refocus on the core issues you agree on, and try to find common ground from which you can build.

3. Use empathy - Try to understand your opponent's point of view, even if you disagree with it. Empathy can help you identify underlying assumptions or beliefs that are contributing to their use of fallacies.

4. Stay respectful - Remember to stay respectful and composed, even if your opponent is being difficult. This will help you maintain the upper ground and avoid escalating the conversation.

5. Keep the audience in mind - If there's an audience involved, try to focus on addressing them instead of your opponent. This can help you avoid getting caught up in unproductive arguments and keep the conversation on track.

At the end of the day, if your opponent continues to use fallacies despite your attempts to reach common ground, you may have to accept that you're not going to change their minds. Focus on presenting your argument clearly and succinctly, and let the evidence speak for itself.
